newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: SLOVAK FINMIN DENIES MULLING CAR DUTY BEFORE '97. [CORRECTED 15:50 gmt]
newsitem.headline: SLOVAK FINMIN DENIES MULLING CAR DUTY BEFORE '97. [CORRECTED 15:50 gmt]

text.p: The Slovak Finance Ministry on Wednesday said it was not considering re-imposing customs duties on imports of new cars with engines of 1,500cc before next year.
Last September, Slovakia temporarily abolished its 19 percent customs duties on imports of new medium-sized cars, though officials said they would review the policy at the beginning of 1997.
Local media, however, have recently reported that the ministry was considering re-implementing the tariffs as a way to help stem the country's widening trade deficit.

"The ministry has not so far prepared any proposal concerning re-imposing custom duties on import of medium-sized cars before the planned date, which is January 1, 1997," Daniela Zvoncakova of the ministry's press department said.
The abolition of the duties was an attempt to aid Slovaks looking to buy medium-sized cars and help eliminate the number of older cars from the road.
Economics Ministry spokesman Jozef Sucha told Reuters the country's trade balance would be the main criterion in considering any re-imposition of the duties at the end of 1996.
Slovakia posted a trade deficit of 26.975 billion crowns in the first half of the year, a dramatic reversal of the 1.8 billion crown surplus posted in 1995 (corrects from "the first half of 1995").
Sucha said he did not expect the zero-level tariff to be maintained after January 1, but would not elaborate on the possible extent of its re-imposition in 1997.
No figures on total imports of new cars with 1,500cc engines for the first half of this year are available, but analysts said car imports comprise a large part of the country's overall imports.

Earlier this year the government decided to completely abolish a widely criticised import surcharge effective January 1, 1997 after heavy pressure from western economic organisations, such as the WTO, and the European Union.
